DEEAWARE RACES.

To The Editors of the National hateMgencer.


GENTLEMEN: observed in your paper, some days
ago. notice that person had discovered a cure for
the use of TOBACCO. | have suffered under pull
monary complaint two years and a half: about the


first of July last was very feeble, when friend ad-
vised me to use Slippery Elm Bark. substitute
for Tobacco: observing that would swallow the
Juice or spittIe, which would be of benefit to the
lungs. l Immediately commenced using it; and.
what has been very surprising to me. from that day
to this never had the least desire for Tobacco, al


though l had used it for upwards of twenty five
wears. l cannot use it now if would: it IS perfect
|ly nauseous to me- I have tried the experiment a
few times, by putting some in my mostb, and have
USE OF TOBACCO.

ii II AMERICAN S1 > EN-.


There are persons who feel an interest in endeas
voring to persuade the farmers Of this neghborhoof
that the protection of domestic manufacturers is ts
them an unilnportant matter-a subject about whtR
they have no cause to give themselves any concern.


60 meet this falacous doctrine, it is necessary only
to state single fact. There were imported irt5
Boston alone, during the last year. for home con-
sumption. SOo,7O4 barrels Of -four. Of these,
ll9, 202 barres-nuch more than one half--wen.
from the port of Baltimore, which is the prihcpals


if not the sole market for the -four produced in York
county. During the same year. the Whole of the
exports Of the article from the United States to Eus
rope amounted to about 56.675 barrels! The des
mand for -four created by the manufacturing estabs


shments in New England, is therefore Of the uts
most Importance to our farfiers One single fiss
trict in New England takes from us three times


more -four than all Europe together; and the ~hts
amount taken by the eastern states exceeds 628.OOO
BARRELS Annhilate that demand, and would not the


farmers of this county feel the effects in all thsif
operations Great clanor is attempted to be raised
against Mr.. Adams administration. becausps through
the perverseness aud obstinacy of the British minis
try. our trade with the British colonies Ia turned
aside from direct to circuitous channe~--and the
farmers are told that they are in consequence sui.
ferine arevousIy. Our produce still finds its Way
to the cuonies, because the planters cannot de ts
out it but if the trade totally losts of what
CONSEQUENCE is that boasted mart in cofipdrisoh
with that of N. England. The colonies take front
us ia 900 barres-New England takes .OO0.
The colonial trade is huctuatlng and precafiods
that with New England is steady and sure. i'Io


latter rests on the broad basis of national policy
and. if the people truc to their own interesfsj


in fostering efecualy and wisely the domestic INDUS
try of the country. it will be permanentas the Uhol,
and Increase and spread as our population, ah with
the deyelupement Of our internal resources. 10 sa-
lisfy themselves that they have an interest tn the ems
courayement Of manufactures our farmers need only
oouire who it is that now buys their flour. and
what it is that keeps up the demand and the price.
Such an inquiry will show the immense advantages
resulting to the farming community from the adcp:a
ton and enforcement Of the American systems !

By the mails of Saturday Evening, the accounts
from below represent the friends Of the Administra
|tion as active and in fine spirits The lowest ma
ior,es in Kent and Sussex from their estimates, are
between and 900 in favor of Mr.. Johns.


Newcastle County will give but a small majority
either way.


All that is desirable is--that every man should 90
to the polls and vote his sentiments.


The aunt of the Lawyers to Sussex has been
productive only Of disgust on the part OF the sober
sided portion Of the community. Should MIR. Payn.
really have been :. rorastrRiaed to decline stand
ing as candidate for the Senate, as bandblll,
posted up in town, states, MIR. Dunnng, one of the
most popular men 10 Sussex. will probably fill the
vacancy


PoWer Loonas.-The power loom invented by tho
Rev. Mr.. Cartwright, clergyman Of Kent. is one
Of the most ingenious, efficient, and we will add,
supereminently useful machines thai has ever been
constructed MIR. Cartwright states in very III
erestng letter addressed by him to Mr.. Bannatyne,
of Glasgow, that the idea Of constructing power
loom was excited in his mind by being in company
with some Manchester gentlemen at Matlock. In
l794.wlo remarked that so many cotton mills would
be erected and much yarn spun, that it Woud be
impossible procure hands to weave it.. Mr. Cart.
wright replied, that Mr.. Arkwrisht must, in that
case set bis wits to work to invent weaving MILL
The Manchester gentlemen all declared that that
was impractcabe i; but Mr. Cartwright denied that
there could be any greater difficulty in nveutjng
machine to weave cotton than to spin it ; and me-
dtatng afterwards on the subject of this conversa.
tion, he succeeded in constructing loom, all the
movements of which were performed by means of
machinery Mr.. Cartwright, took out patent for
his invention in 1887. The progress of power loom
weaving was not at first rapid might have been
expected. That arose partly from the lmperfectons
that originally attached to the machine, but chiefly
to the circumstance of its being necessary to dress
the webs from time to time after they put into
the looms. which made 1t impossible for one person
to do more than attend to one loom. But beautiful
machine, invented by Mr.. Thomas Johnspn,of Brad
bury, for warping and dressing the yarh used a.
warps, has completely obviated this difficulty; and
at this moment, boy grl. of from twelve to tour
teen years of age with ease attend to two pow
Ier looms-and can, by their means, produce ttres
times as much we'll woven cloth as could be produes
ed by the best hand weaver During the last ten


years. the number Of power looms increased with as.
ltonishng rapidity. According to Mr.. Banps there
were, in 1918, in Manchester, Stockport and the


immediate vicinity, about 1000 power looms Ii,


1921 they had increased to 5732 and in July 1925.


in the parish Of Manchester alone, they amounted to
upwards of 2000O4 There are now. probably, a.
bout 45 900 power-loon,s in great Britain, employed


in the weaving of cotton only, exclusive of those ems


poyed in the weaving of wool and of these there
are supposed to be about 5000 i'll Scotland. i Ed
inburgh Review.l

yer on the 22nd, "without any understanding with

his friends an undivided support OF man who has
alled Jack -on 'da1,n'd old cut throat'-atter hav-

the original intention as soon all the arrange.
spents suere completed, is scarcely credible. The
Ja,,Son ticket, therefore, as we apprehend, means
in the estimation of MIR. Whiteley. the ticket tol
Senator and House of Representatives OF the State
nominated at Chrisliana. Such ticket, we have
no doubt will be well supported by the party gener
ally: but it Is notorious that no recommendation o
Mr. Nhiteley, even if he could be prevailed upoI


ny ''oher reasons" to give it in favour OF TIT


dann'd old cut throat candidate, could possibl,


produce an i" undivided support" on the part OF hi
! friends.


Mr.. Whiteley not only writes like aninjured man


but is felt the part Of his friends that he ha


been badly treated. His claims to support o.


NLme and Ridgcly were great. But they all mus


be forgotten, as soon as it was thought that tn


rigiaM Jucksonia,as Were so bound that the Mana


GERS could carry into effect their first intentions


We shall see.

Jack, the 3 year old, is IA high metted, fiery col
He has been we'll fed, comes of good strair
and has long been n training by few KNOWN

Having now few more owners than formerly, the

Jack will abour under several disadvantages
Some Of the owners having great partiaty for th

Jack, but rather secretly, if not openly, throw ob
stacies in his way, and indeed its thought that the,

which it is probable will be the case


Further: Jack has been unfortunate in the side
allotted to him while .8daan has the right. beau
tiful and smooth course, Jack has the left, more
rough, and zigzag-belng quite unfavourable to a
young horse.


When Jack was voung--perhaps in his first year
he happened to run into heap OF piastering mor.
fer while was so hot as to scald his feet very much
He has since been extremely skttish at seeing such
heaps. Notwithstanding his keepers have tried all
their skill to cure him and as there are several o
such heaps lying to the course it is calculated
on all hands. it will stop his speed considerably.


Again from the circumstance of a chimney neal
his stable taking fire and frightening him very much
it is feared, should he see the smuke ascending
from the chimnies iu the neighbourng houses, he
will take fright and fly the course, or make some
balk.


Further tits asserted that Jack some time ago
when brought in view OF the course which he il
now to run, appeared in great rage, and bellowe,
loudly, in a voice SO much resembling human, tha
the spectators all agree that that it sounded some
thing like :. damned old cat Mroat!'' Itis feared tha
this old aversion still exists. notwithstanding tb,
pains taken to remove it though most persons hop,
it will not be shown during the race. Jack has, al
80, been considerably injured in his speed by severa
accidents especially BY kick he lately received il
the Hall. frum large, fat, draft horse, called DAY

ATTENTION


I'm .a5stract Of the act regulating the Gener
= Election, passed at Douer. Jan'y 90, 1925.
Section 5. The Sheriff of each Caunty shall de

.4nterican System--Facts speak for themselves,
and contradict predictions of those opposed to the
protection of our national industry. In every in
stance where the government has by high duty ena-
bed the American to get to work before he was ruin
ed by British capitalists, the article protected has
fell in price to the consumer. Plain cotton cloth
sold (of an inferior quality at 80 cents; better can
now be had at cents the yard and in place OF send
ing money to India to purchase humhuns our ou'
ward bound vessels take large quantities OF cotton
cloth to that country. Spun cotton before the high
protecting duty was imposed sold at the northern
factories at from 70 to IS cents, by the quantity
the same quality OF yarn can now be had In any
quantity, at % cents, whilst the English price cur
rent quotes the lowest prices at more that q cents
per Id. and in few years we anticipate that ship
nents of cotton yarn of cloth. will be made to Great
Britain in place Of the raw material. When the du-
ty on cut nail, was laid, the price was 10 cents the
Id. now any quantity can be had I'm Aexandrla) at
seven cents The price of writing paper, when the
duty was laid, was for No. /, about IS 50 it can
now be had at IS IS. These are facts which ad-
NIT of no dispute, and establish the principle we
have ever advocated. Give American enterprise d
fair start, and the genius Of the people will ensure
success to the exertions of freemer.


| One striking advantage is mentioned by every per-
son who has visited any OF the northern manufaeur-
ing villages. The poor class are without exception,
well provided for-thelr wages keep them from want,
and the knowledge of their ability to maintain them
selves has removed that debasement that exists IN
the lower rank of this and other states The rising
generation by this means prepared to act an non
orable part in after life, and feel some Of that pride
which should be cherished in the bosom Of every
freeman.


1t is certainly sound policy to encourage the max
ing of every article necessary in the event OF for
eign war. No person conversant with the evils en-
countered in the last war; be ratorous to their
country as to wish to have them again encountered.
From. the TiIrginia Gazette.

from the boston courier


The New-Ynrk Gazette states that the amount of
revenue to the customs in that city already exceeds
the amount received during the whole of last year.
This is very tiatterng, and we glad to hear such
good accounts Of the commercial prosperity of the
country. Boston. too, is doing better this year than
usual and we have heard it asserted many times
lately. bv those whose opinions entitled to much
weight. that the summer months have not been so
ivel, for many years. The fall business has com
menced early and prosperously. 1t highly proba-
Bile that like our sister city Of New York. the revenue
to the customs from Boston, will far exceed that of
last year.. -


WAsHINGToN, SEPTEMBER "a.


We learn that two Con ventions between the
UNITED STATES and GREAT BRITAIN have been re-
ceised at the Department of State, which were
cuded and signed in the early part Of last month,a
few days before Mr.. CANNING's death, by Mr.. GAL
LATIN, and Messrs. GRANT and ApDINetoN. BY
one Of them. the Third Article of the Convention
Of sis which stipulates the joint occupation of the
country beyond the Stony Mountains, is continued;
and, by the other, the Commercial Convention Of
1915, which was continued by the abov ementioned
Convention ofl8lS, is further coninued.the duration
If the Convention of 1873, having been limited to
ten years. which would have expired the Goth OF
October, 1923, Oh that day the existing Commercial
Convention and the Article respecting the country
beyond the Rocky Mountains, would have terminal
cd. but for the recent Conventions. They are now
to continue indefinitely as to time, each party re-
serving the right, to put end to either Of them
upon twelve months notice given to the other Party
THE REVENUE.

sumption. SOo,7O4 barrels Of -four. Of these,
ll9, 202 barres-nuch more than one half--wen.
from the port of Baltimore, which is the prihcpals


if not the sole market for the -four produced in York

exports Of the article from the United States to Eus
rope amounted to about 56.675 barrels! The des
mand for -four created by the manufacturing estabs


shments in New England, is therefore Of the uts
most Importance to our farfiers One single fiss
trict in New England takes from us three times


more -four than all Europe together; and the ~hts
amount taken by the eastern states exceeds 628.OOO
BARRELS Annhilate that demand, and would not the


farmers of this county feel the effects in all thsif

against Mr.. Adams administration. becausps through
the perverseness aud obstinacy of the British minis
try. our trade with the British colonies Ia turned
aside from direct to circuitous channe~--and the

ferine arevousIy. Our produce still finds its Way
to the cuonies, because the planters cannot de ts
out it but if the trade totally losts of what
CONSEQUENCE is that boasted mart in cofipdrisoh
with that of N. England. The colonies take front
us ia 900 barres-New England takes .OO0.
The colonial trade is huctuatlng and precafiods
that with New England is steady and sure. i'Io


latter rests on the broad basis of national policy
and. if the people truc to their own interesfsj


in fostering efecualy and wisely the domestic INDUS
try of the country. it will be permanentas the Uhol,
and Increase and spread as our population, ah with

lisfy themselves that they have an interest tn the ems

Such an inquiry will show the immense advantages

full articles.headline:
POSTSCRIPT

THE ELECTION.
full articles.article:
By the mails of Saturday Evening, the accounts
from below represent the friends Of the Administra
|tion as active and in fine spirits The lowest ma
ior,es in Kent and Sussex from their estimates, are
between and 900 in favor of Mr.. Johns.


Newcastle County will give but a small majority
either way.


All that is desirable is--that every man should 90
to the polls and vote his sentiments.


The aunt of the Lawyers to Sussex has been
productive only Of disgust on the part OF the sober
sided portion Of the community. Should MIR. Payn.
really have been :. rorastrRiaed to decline stand
ing as candidate for the Senate, as bandblll,
posted up in town, states, MIR. Dunnng, one of the
most popular men 10 Sussex. will probably fill the
vacancy


PoWer Loonas.-The power loom invented by tho
Rev. Mr.. Cartwright, clergyman Of Kent. is one
Of the most ingenious, efficient, and we will add,
supereminently useful machines thai has ever been
constructed MIR. Cartwright states in very III
erestng letter addressed by him to Mr.. Bannatyne,
of Glasgow, that the idea Of constructing power
loom was excited in his mind by being in company
with some Manchester gentlemen at Matlock. In
l794.wlo remarked that so many cotton mills would
be erected and much yarn spun, that it Woud be
impossible procure hands to weave it.. Mr. Cart.
wright replied, that Mr.. Arkwrisht must, in that
case set bis wits to work to invent weaving MILL
The Manchester gentlemen all declared that that
was impractcabe i; but Mr. Cartwright denied that
there could be any greater difficulty in nveutjng
machine to weave cotton than to spin it ; and me-
dtatng afterwards on the subject of this conversa.
tion, he succeeded in constructing loom, all the
movements of which were performed by means of
machinery Mr.. Cartwright, took out patent for
his invention in 1887. The progress of power loom
weaving was not at first rapid might have been
expected. That arose partly from the lmperfectons
that originally attached to the machine, but chiefly
to the circumstance of its being necessary to dress
the webs from time to time after they put into
the looms. which made 1t impossible for one person
to do more than attend to one loom. But beautiful
machine, invented by Mr.. Thomas Johnspn,of Brad
bury, for warping and dressing the yarh used a.
warps, has completely obviated this difficulty; and
at this moment, boy grl. of from twelve to tour
teen years of age with ease attend to two pow
Ier looms-and can, by their means, produce ttres
times as much we'll woven cloth as could be produes
ed by the best hand weaver During the last ten


years. the number Of power looms increased with as.
ltonishng rapidity. According to Mr.. Banps there
were, in 1918, in Manchester, Stockport and the


immediate vicinity, about 1000 power looms Ii,


1921 they had increased to 5732 and in July 1925.


in the parish Of Manchester alone, they amounted to
upwards of 2000O4 There are now. probably, a.
bout 45 900 power-loon,s in great Britain, employed


in the weaving of cotton only, exclusive of those ems


poyed in the weaving of wool and of these there
are supposed to be about 5000 i'll Scotland. i Ed
inburgh Review.l


l

at being stated to the meeting that Col. Henry

Again-in the account Of the same proceedings

Thus we see how kind some Friend must have been.

snion, AFTER ALL THE ARRANGEMENTS

lIr. Whiteley, being an original Jacksohian re-

port TO the Jackson Ticket" Now, whether Mr.
| Whiteley considers the candidate nominated at Do
yer on the 22nd, "without any understanding with

stated in his card. Thathe could recommend to
his friends an undivided support OF man who has
alled Jack -on 'da1,n'd old cut throat'-atter hav-
| ing himself been thrown over board, according to
the original intention as soon all the arrange.
spents suere completed, is scarcely credible. The
Ja,,Son ticket, therefore, as we apprehend, means
in the estimation of MIR. Whiteley. the ticket tol
Senator and House of Representatives OF the State
nominated at Chrisliana. Such ticket, we have
no doubt will be well supported by the party gener
ally: but it Is notorious that no recommendation o
Mr. Nhiteley, even if he could be prevailed upoI


ny ''oher reasons" to give it in favour OF TIT


dann'd old cut throat candidate, could possibl,


produce an i" undivided support" on the part OF hi
! friends.


Mr.. Whiteley not only writes like aninjured man


but is felt the part Of his friends that he ha


been badly treated. His claims to support o.


NLme and Ridgcly were great. But they all mus


be forgotten, as soon as it was thought that tn


rigiaM Jucksonia,as Were so bound that the Mana


GERS could carry into effect their first intentions


We shall see.

Iirmation, if SO required, shall not be permitted to
vote but no person shall be required permitted
to take either Of the said oaths or afirmatons. if
the Judges shall from their own knowledge, the
circumstances appearing, consider that suc! per-
son is not entitled to vote.


Sec. IA. The penalty for receiving knowingly
the vote ofa person not entitled to vote. Five Hun
dred Dollars. to any person who will sue for the
same-and shall be adudged guilty of perjury. &c.


Sec IS. Penalty for refusing the vote Of per-
son entitled to vote, Fifty Dollars.


Sec. 10, lfany person not entitled to vote, shall
vote, offer to vute-or shall vote OF offer to vote
in hundred in which he shall not reside--or shall
vote a second time at the same election, or in two
different hundreds, or shall deliver or offer more
than single ballot every such person shall forfeit
and pay the sum of One Hundred Dollars to any per-
who will sue for the same.


Sec. "a. If any person shall give, offer, or pro-
mise any reward gift favor Or benefit. to any man,
to hire, brbe, or influence him in giving his vote,
or if any candidate shall influence or attempt to in
1uence any man, by any brbe, reward or promise of
favor or bencit--every such person or candidate
shall forfeit to the State fine not less than Fifty.
nor more than Two Hundred Dollars.

him the best side ofthe course, which is free fro.
impediments, bets at present are much in his iovo
especially as his wind is SO remarkably good.


Jack, the 3 year old, is IA high metted, fiery col
He has been we'll fed, comes of good strair
and has long been n training by few KNOWN
Jockies but he labors under several disadvantages
Having now few more owners than formerly, the
have wrangled no little about hin,-sometilnes i
doubt whether to run him, or one. of their othe
colts, Black, Read, or Whiteley Indeed, at on
time they brought Whteley fairly on the course
and actually troted him round to try him, that th
puhc--(but not few Of the knowing ones) bega
TO think that he to contend with Adam. A
length, arrangements being made, the original in
tention was carried into effect, and tho Whitele
was led off, and the Jack colt announced the bes
colt they could produce. But it is thought by GOO
Judges that the Whiteley would have made mucl
better race, especially the first and second rounds


Jack will abour under several disadvantages
Some Of the owners having great partiaty for th
tkhiteley colt, are quite dissatisfied at the reamen
he has received. and are determined not to bet ol
Jack, but rather secretly, if not openly, throw ob
stacies in his way, and indeed its thought that the,
will rejoice to see him distanced the first heat
which it is probable will be the case


Further: Jack has been unfortunate in the side
allotted to him while .8daan has the right. beau
tiful and smooth course, Jack has the left, more
rough, and zigzag-belng quite unfavourable to a
young horse.


When Jack was voung--perhaps in his first year
he happened to run into heap OF piastering mor.
fer while was so hot as to scald his feet very much
He has since been extremely skttish at seeing such
heaps. Notwithstanding his keepers have tried all
their skill to cure him and as there are several o
such heaps lying to the course it is calculated
on all hands. it will stop his speed considerably.


Again from the circumstance of a chimney neal
his stable taking fire and frightening him very much
it is feared, should he see the smuke ascending
from the chimnies iu the neighbourng houses, he
will take fright and fly the course, or make some
balk.


Further tits asserted that Jack some time ago
when brought in view OF the course which he il
now to run, appeared in great rage, and bellowe,
loudly, in a voice SO much resembling human, tha
the spectators all agree that that it sounded some
thing like :. damned old cat Mroat!'' Itis feared tha
this old aversion still exists. notwithstanding tb,
pains taken to remove it though most persons hop,
it will not be shown during the race. Jack has, al
80, been considerably injured in his speed by severa
accidents especially BY kick he lately received il
the Hall. frum large, fat, draft horse, called DAY
LABOURER


Jacks keepers. however, are sparing no pains
seeking, especially on Sundays for the most whole
some food, OIL &c. &c. and rubbing him down il
fine style. Having heard that there was an excel
lent oil in Sussex, which never failed in the case i
Jacks sire, the two head grooms left here on Sun
day week to get supply of it, with what success
we have not learned but it is supposed as they stat
all night at small establishment called Butter Poi
4 in Kent forest (we known to some members of tn
Legislature from this County as place of resort las
winter. which indicates greasy or oily place, the
will at least pass it off for Sussex oil, whether it an
swers the purpose or not. | had well nigh forgot


ten to mention that they met in Georgetown wit
! an unhappy incident-one Of the groons OF AtIat
coming in contact with them gave him severe l1sl
circumstance it is supposed FASTENED their return
They report having caught Paytter-doubed.
Upon the whole. the race will be hardly contest
ed by some of the friends of Jack. as some of tn
heaviest betters have saked their last cent and Sc,
eral of the smaller ones all, except little loo,
change Should the purse be won by .4iam. it


pretty certain there will be no races here next fall
unless it be few sc,7tb& the principals will nj
be able to raise another purse and little Sammy WI


cleans the stable and does all the dirtiest Jobs h;
labored so hard and halooed 80 loud that he is no
broken -wnded, and will be left to die in the ditch
have given the Jockies, on both sides. my view
of the race. leaving them to bet they see proper
but I'll give two to one in favor of .Adanl

full articles.headline: From. the TiIrginia Gazette.
full articles.article:
.4nterican System--Facts speak for themselves,
and contradict predictions of those opposed to the
protection of our national industry. In every in
stance where the government has by high duty ena-
bed the American to get to work before he was ruin
ed by British capitalists, the article protected has
fell in price to the consumer. Plain cotton cloth
sold (of an inferior quality at 80 cents; better can
now be had at cents the yard and in place OF send
ing money to India to purchase humhuns our ou'
ward bound vessels take large quantities OF cotton
cloth to that country. Spun cotton before the high
protecting duty was imposed sold at the northern
factories at from 70 to IS cents, by the quantity
the same quality OF yarn can now be had In any
quantity, at % cents, whilst the English price cur
rent quotes the lowest prices at more that q cents
per Id. and in few years we anticipate that ship
nents of cotton yarn of cloth. will be made to Great
Britain in place Of the raw material. When the du-
ty on cut nail, was laid, the price was 10 cents the
Id. now any quantity can be had I'm Aexandrla) at
seven cents The price of writing paper, when the
duty was laid, was for No. /, about IS 50 it can
now be had at IS IS. These are facts which ad-
NIT of no dispute, and establish the principle we
have ever advocated. Give American enterprise d
fair start, and the genius Of the people will ensure
success to the exertions of freemer.


| One striking advantage is mentioned by every per-
son who has visited any OF the northern manufaeur-
ing villages. The poor class are without exception,
well provided for-thelr wages keep them from want,
and the knowledge of their ability to maintain them
selves has removed that debasement that exists IN
the lower rank of this and other states The rising
generation by this means prepared to act an non
orable part in after life, and feel some Of that pride
which should be cherished in the bosom Of every
freeman.


1t is certainly sound policy to encourage the max
ing of every article necessary in the event OF for
eign war. No person conversant with the evils en-
countered in the last war; be ratorous to their
country as to wish to have them again encountered.

full articles.headline: THE REVENUE.
full articles.article:
from the boston courier


The New-Ynrk Gazette states that the amount of
revenue to the customs in that city already exceeds
the amount received during the whole of last year.
This is very tiatterng, and we glad to hear such
good accounts Of the commercial prosperity of the
country. Boston. too, is doing better this year than
usual and we have heard it asserted many times
lately. bv those whose opinions entitled to much
weight. that the summer months have not been so
ivel, for many years. The fall business has com
menced early and prosperously. 1t highly proba-
Bile that like our sister city Of New York. the revenue
to the customs from Boston, will far exceed that of
last year.. -


WAsHINGToN, SEPTEMBER "a.


We learn that two Con ventions between the
UNITED STATES and GREAT BRITAIN have been re-
ceised at the Department of State, which were
cuded and signed in the early part Of last month,a
few days before Mr.. CANNING's death, by Mr.. GAL
LATIN, and Messrs. GRANT and ApDINetoN. BY
one Of them. the Third Article of the Convention
Of sis which stipulates the joint occupation of the
country beyond the Stony Mountains, is continued;
and, by the other, the Commercial Convention Of
1915, which was continued by the abov ementioned
Convention ofl8lS, is further coninued.the duration
If the Convention of 1873, having been limited to
ten years. which would have expired the Goth OF
October, 1923, Oh that day the existing Commercial
Convention and the Article respecting the country
beyond the Rocky Mountains, would have terminal
cd. but for the recent Conventions. They are now
to continue indefinitely as to time, each party re-
serving the right, to put end to either Of them
upon twelve months notice given to the other Party
